title: 111_hr4249
content: The "Commission On Reforming Entitlement Spending Act" or the "CORE Spending Act" establishes a commission tasked with reforming entitlement spending. The Commission established by the "CORE Spending Act" will develop legislation to address long-term fiscal challenges, including unsustainable spending commitments, increasing national savings, foreign debt ownership implications, and budget process improvements. Legislation may include entitlement growth reforms. The Commission established by the "CORE Spending Act" will develop legislation to address long-term fiscal challenges, including reforms to limit entitlement spending growth, strengthen safety net functions, increase private savings, and enforce spending and revenue targets without new federal taxes. The Commission, with a 5-member vote, will develop up to 2 alternative methods for estimating legislation costs, focusing on addressing flaws in the current method for estimating positive economic effects. The Commission will hold town hall style public hearings in each Federal reserve district to ensure broad public participation. The hearings will focus on presenting issues, policies, and tradeoffs related to the legislation. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the President within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include a description of the Commission's activities, feedback from town hall style public hearings, public preferences on presented issues, long-term fiscal problems of the US, policy options to address these problems, and criteria for the legislative proposal. The Commission will submit a legislative proposal to Congress and the President within 60 days of the report submission. The proposal aims to achieve generational equity, address public feedback, and meet the criteria set in the Commission report. It must include a long-term CBO cost estimate and a 50-year cost estimate if an alternative method is used. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP AND MEETINGS. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by various officials and 2 nonvoting members who advise and assist the Commission. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by various officials and 2 nonvoting members who advise and assist at the request of the Commission. Each appointing authority, if a Member of Congress, can only appoint 1 Member of Congress to the Commission. The initial members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, with terms lasting for the life of the Commission. Vacancies must be filled within 30 days in the same manner as the original appointment. Members of the Commission do not receive compensation, except as provided. Members of the Commission do not receive compensation, except for travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the chairperson or a majority of its voting members, with a quorum of six voting members required for meetings. SEC. 8. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission appoints a director who is responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. The director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission appoints a director responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. The director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The competitive service allows for pay up to $150,000 per year without regard to classification rules. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their employment rights. The director can procure expert services as needed. The director can procure expert services under appropriation Acts at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services upon request. Additionally, the Commission may enter into contracts, accept gifts, and donations of services or property to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. SEC. 10. TERMINATION. The Commission will end 60 days after submitting its legislative proposal. SEC. 11. ALTERNATIVE LEGISLATIVE PROPOSAL OF PRESIDENT. The President can submit an alternative legislative proposal to Congress within 60 days of the Commission's submission. SEC. 12. ALTERNATIVE LEGISLATIVE PROPOSAL OF THE COMMITTEE ON THE BUDGET. The Committee on the Budget can publish an alternative legislative proposal in the Congressional Record within 60 days of the Commission's submission. SEC. 13. CONSIDERATION OF LEGISLATION. The Speaker of the House and Majority Leader of the Senate will introduce the legislation submitted by the Commission. In the House of Representatives, if a committee does not report the legislation within 60 days, the committee will be discharged, and the legislation will be placed on the calendar for consideration. Amendments to the legislation are limited. Amendments to the legislation are limited in the House of Representatives. Members can offer alternative legislative proposals as amendments in the nature of a substitute, including those submitted by the President or the Commission. The chairman of the House Committee on the Budget can also offer alternative legislative proposals published in the Congressional Record. Points of order may be raised for amendments not accompanied by a long-term CBO cost estimate or if the estimate exceeds that of the legislative proposal. Multiple amendments under this rule are considered separately, with the one receiving a majority and highest votes being adopted. SEC. 14. LONG-TERM CBO COST ESTIMATE. The Director of the Congressional Budget Office must provide a long-term cost estimate for proposed legislation or amendments upon request, detailing costs for the first fiscal year and the following 50 years. Any future costs not included in the estimate must also be disclosed.
